subject: Psychology
title: Good Habits Bad Habits
description: A 60-second lesson on Good Habits Bad Habits.

hook.text: Brushing your teeth is a good habit. Nail biting is a bad one. Both run on the same brain machinery.

buildup.text: The brain doesn't judge whether a habit is helpful or harmful. It just automates whatever gets repeated.

discovery.text: Good habits reduce friction toward desired outcomes. Bad habits create friction against your own goals.

twist.text: Bad habits aren't character flaws. They're learned responses that once served a purpose â€” comfort, relief, escape.

climax.text: Labeling habits as 'good' or 'bad' is less useful than asking: does this habit serve me or work against me?

punchline.text: The brain doesn't care if a habit helps or hurts. It just repeats.

quiz.question: Why does the brain form bad habits?
options: It automates whatever gets repeated regardless of benefit
The brain only forms helpful habits
Bad habits are caused by low intelligence
